 Right now in the Netherlands doctors are legally allowed to euthanize at their discretion. 
 
 http://apnews.myway.com/article/20050330/D8959DCO0.html
 
 You may say, thats the Netherlands, this is America. Well, I fear America is only steps behind them. With a large amount of our judges basing their decisions on international law it is a matter of time before we are dealing with these issues.  You may say, thats the Netherlands, this is America. Well, I fear America is only steps behind them. With a large amount of our judges basing their decisions on international law it is a matter of time before we are dealing with these issues. In the future with the aging of the baby boomers, there will be an huge economic pressure to cut health care costs. I think this will become an option, and the mindset that says that there is no intrinsic value to the human being and no right to life is paving the way. 

 Contrary to what you might believe, human life still has value here in Holland. For example, unlike the US, my country doesn't have a death penalty. 
 But the thing is, we also look at the quality of life. What use is it to be alive if you're just trapped inside your own body, unable to do anything?
 
 Basically it's all about what the majority wants because that's what democracy is, the dictatorship of the majority. Two thirds of the people in Holland are not religious, so our views on life may differ greatly from those in the US. There is no right or wrong in this matter, only opinion.
 
 My father had my grandfather euthanised after leukemia ate away his brain and took away his sanity and his dignity. I will do the same to my father when the time comes, and if I have any children in the future I will expect them to do the same for me.

I think this will become an option, and the mindset that says that there is no intrinsic value to the human being and no right to life is paving the way.

 
 Until about WW2, midwives in the US commonly made those decisions for deformed births. With regard to prolonged existence for obviously vegetative state adults, the massive public funds required to sustain them simply weren't available as society attempted to care for those who were capable of returning to society as a contributing member. 
 
 I agree future US economic necessity will eventually force a decline of public funds being devoted to care for vegetative state individuals, but not until belief system fundamentalists are put in a position of caring for them with personal, rather than public funds. Most people simply have no comprehension of the involved costs, nor do they care as long as public money is being used to perpetuate their mythology.

I'm sorry, but I fail to see any kind of connection between Nazi's killing 6 million Jews because they were a scapegoat and a single woman being euthanised after years of litigation in over 20 courts of justice. Even with my rather large imagination it still seems extremely farfetched.
 
 
 
 
 Contrary to what you might believe, human life still has value here in Holland. For example, unlike the US, my country doesn't have a death penalty. 
 But the thing is, we also look at the quality of life. What use is it to be alive if you're just trapped inside your own body, unable to do anything?
 
 Basically it's all about what the majority wants because that's what democracy is, the dictatorship of the majority. Two thirds of the people in Holland are not religious, so our views on life may differ greatly from those in the US. There is no right or wrong in this matter, only opinion.
 
 My father had my grandfather euthanised after leukemia ate away his brain and took away his sanity and his dignity. I will do the same to my father when the time comes, and if I have any children in the future I will expect them to do the same for me.

 
 I believe I read recently that the Netherlands was rated the #1 country for best overall quality of life in the world.

I'm a traditional conservative who views wasting public funds on maintaining vegetative state people a disservice to the country.  No offense, but that is a sick way to think about something. Glad to know we can put a price on a life. When ones values money over life we have a serious problem in this country. It really goes against everything we stand for. One cannot be free if they are controlled by money. I happen to think that everyone is equal....everyone....Mentally retarded, no legs, one eye, anything. No offense, but that is a sick way to think about something. Glad to know we can put a price on a life. When ones values money over life we have a serious problem in this country.

 
 I wouldn't say money, resources is a better word. Here's a good example, say you are adopting a baby as you are very emotionally stressed by your (wife's) recent miscarriage; you are offered a healthy baby boy, next you are offered a near-dead baby boy with less than a day to live. Which are you more likely to choose. In this instance, the former would most likely be chosen, as the adopter is looking for something that will last longer than a day. The adopter has put a value on human life, or lack of it.
 
 Now, a functioning human adult should be able to be left in a house with food, water and air and survive. This is not the case with Terry Schiavo, she would have died in about month, probably less. At this point she's not really alive, for instance, if I beat her with a club would she be able to respond? I believe catalyst and response is a requirement of life, and Terry Schiavo showed no evidence of such a thing. You would think that it's a horrible thing to do, but it's the same as putting a dog to sleep; and I for one am just totally against that being legal! (note terrible use of sarcasm, comment as you like)

 May I remind you the public supported entering Iraq under the illusion of WMDs? And has since been refocused several times. Rationalization is the same as cheap talk, believing it puts people on a subservient level. 
 
 Not following organized spectator sports or using them as viewpoints leaves that one out to dry, un-American I'm sure. To me simply a matter of throwing money at the best talent available and developing it with a competent manager and favorable breaks. Having managed groups of well-educated, bright individuals, I do understand the importance of teamwork to some, which is why society is structured with more workers than anything else. They require direction, adopt popular and peer group opinions as their own with most things always remaining a little out of reach. Makes for a very stable, docile work force with the shortcomings of inability to question tradition and a lack of adaptability to innovation. That's how one sorts out the managers.
